articles.title: The Future of Artificial Intelligence
articles.excerpt: AI is rapidly evolving and reshaping every part of our lives — from creativity to science.
content: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is progressing at a pace never seen before in human history.
Technologies such as neural networks, large language models, and autonomous systems are becoming more capable every year.
AI is not only automating repetitive tasks but also assisting in creativity, scientific discovery, medicine, and space exploration.
As we integrate AI into society, we must consider ethics, safety, accessibility, and education.
The future of AI is not about replacing humans — it is about enhancing what humans can achieve.

articles.title: How to Learn Programming Fast
articles.excerpt: A complete guide to learning programming from zero to professional — the smart and modern way.
content: Learning to code is not about memorizing syntax — it's about understanding how computers think.
Start with one language, preferably Python or JavaScript, and master the basics deeply.
Practice by building small projects: calculators, simple websites, todo apps, etc.
Use spaced repetition, real-world tasks, and consistent daily practice.
Avoid tutorial addiction — build real things as early as possible.

articles.title: The History of the Internet
articles.excerpt: From military networks to global social media — the internet has an incredible story.
content: The internet began as ARPANET, a U.S. military research project created in the 1960s.
It was designed to allow computers to communicate even if parts of the network were damaged.
In the 1990s, the World Wide Web was invented by Tim Berners-Lee, transforming the internet forever.
Social networks, e-commerce, and streaming platforms created the digital world we know today.
Today, billions of devices are connected, creating endless possibilities for communication, learning, and innovation.

articles.title: Quantum Computing Explained
articles.excerpt: Quantum computers use the strange world of quantum physics to solve problems classical computers cannot.
content: Quantum computing is based on qubits, which can exist in multiple states at once.
This concept, called superposition, allows quantum computers to perform many calculations simultaneously.
Entanglement enables qubits to affect each other instantly, even if separated by long distances.
Quantum computers are ideal for cryptography, molecular modeling, optimization, and physics simulations.
Although still experimental, quantum computing has the potential to revolutionize technology.
